headline: Peppy's Pita Bread
description: It's easy to make homemade pita-style bread in your own oven using this easy-to-follow recipe.

video.description: It’s easy to make homemade pita bread.
video.name: Peppy's Pita Bread

name: Peppy's Pita Bread
recipeIngredient: 1.125 cups warm water (110 degrees F/45 degrees C)

recipeInstructions.text: Place all ingredients in bread pan of your bread machine, select Dough setting and start. When dough has risen long enough, machine will beep.

Turn dough onto a lightly floured surface. Gently roll and stretch dough into a 12 inch rope. With a sharp knife, divide dough into 8 pieces. Roll each into a smooth ball. With a rolling pin, roll each ball into a 6 to 7 inch circle. Set aside on a lightly floured countertop. cover with a towel. Let pitas rise about 30 minutes until slightly puffy.

Preheat oven to 500 degrees F (260 degrees C). Place 2 or 3 pitas on a wire cake rack. Place cake rack directly on oven rack. Bake pitas 4 to 5 minutes until puffed and tops begin to brown. Remove from oven and immediately place pitas in a sealed brown paper bag or cover them with a damp kitchen towel until soft. Once pitas a softened, either cut in half or split top edge for half or whole pitas. They can be stored in a plastic bag in the refrigerator for several days or in the freezer for 1 or 2 months.

To make pitas puff, you need the outside to cook before the water on the inside turns to steam. If you followed the recipe and your pitas didn't puff, they probably didn't get hot fast enough or didn't form a solid crust. Personally, I like them better that way. To make them puff you can add extra water to the dough after the first rise, or add a bowl of water to the oven while baking. To make them hotter, you can use a preheated pizza stone or baking sheet, the broil button or cook them in a skillet on the stove top. To make them smoother with a more even thickness, you can let them rise the second time on cookie sheets and put those into the oven to avoid overhandling the pitas, or you can roll them back into a ball after the second rise and roll them out again just before you bake them. They'll get smaller, but somehow not noticeably denser.

Make sure to roll the edges really flat for max puffiness! Even unpuffed, this stuff is amazing and my whole family happily devoured it.

Then put it in my kitchenaid mixer with the dough hook on slow until it all became dough. I let it rise for an hour in a glass bowl covered by a towel. From then on I followed instructions. I liked the ones that turned a little bit brown, but really all were perfect pita. Thank you Peppy!
Loved this recipe! I usually have a hard time working with dough and this was surprisingly easy. Stuck to the recipe for exactly, except mine required longer cook time (7-10 minutes). Delicious!
This is the first consistent pita recipe I've found. Excellent and easy!

Thanks!

I add to cloves of minced garlic.
Yummy!

My husband likes when it brown on both sides. If this is what your looking for brush only the top side with milk, if you do both sides it will stick (I have tried)

So easy to make! I did half whole wheat, half all purpose, some gluten, garlic powder, and caraway seeds. Made it according to directions, but used the chef John pita directions, as I didn't want to make a mess in my oven. 

My husband already ate 2 as is and claims they are the best pitas he's ever had. I'll definitely make this instead of buying from the store in the future. So much better and more affordable.

I followed this recipe exactly as written, except I shortened the rise times. The pitas puffed up beautifully and split perfectly. I let the dough rise till double in my bread machine, which was only 30 minutes. (My bread machine dough cycle is 1.5 hours.) After rolling out, I let the dough disks rest for 20 minutes then baked for 5 minutes. I think this recipe is my new “go-to” for sandwich bread!
I make this recipe at least once a week. Has turned out perfect everytime for several years now. Super easy!

These were wonderful! First time ever making pitas so I spent the cooking time staring into the oven to be sure nothing burned. I didn't change a thing about the recipe, just made it as is, and it came out amazing. This one is a keeper.

Thanks for the great recipe and the modifications!!!
Fabulous! I made this as written, using my bread maker, and it turned out great. Easy to follow recipe, simple ingredients and not too time consuming. I will definitely be using this recipe again.

Followed recipe exactly but do not own a bread maker, so proofed the yeast with sugar and 1/4c warm water for about 10 minutes then mixed all ingredients together and kneaded dough until smooth and elastic on lightly floured surface. Followed remaining instructions and the results were fabulous fresh pitas with nice "pocketability" :)
Easy to make, come out perfectly!

This pita was excellent and just as good as that of the high-end restaurants and middle eastern grocery stores. I did not use a bread machine but making the dough took about five minutes. Cooking them was a breeze and the looked, felt and tasted amazing.

Amazing recipe! I'm still in SHOCK that I made pita bread from my kitchen. Since I didn't have a cake rack, I put aluminum foil directly on the over rack. This required about 2 extra minutes of baking (12 total). Also, I did this without a bread machine. Proofed my yeast with 1t sugar and warm water- let it sit for 10 mins. Then mix in with remaining ingredients with your hands. The rest is history!

A General Note to Everyone:

Every so often I see comments here questioning how or in what order to add ingredients to a bread machine. The key here is to follow the directions that CAME WITH YOUR MACHINE!! Some manufacturers say to put all the liquids in first and then the dry. Others say to do the opposite. I'm not sure how the machine knows what to do with them, but my Oster dictates wet items first, so that's what I do. I've never had a bad loaf yet, and I've been using it for over two years now.

I have made this at least 5 times. Exactly as written is great. Like some others don't have a bread machine so kitchenaide to the rescue. I have also made it by hand and it is an easy knead. The dough is slightly sticky so just added a Tbsp of flour at a time while mixing until I get the right consistency/texture. This batch I added a tsp of dried dill, 1/2 tsp of cumin seed and 1 tsp of reconstituted onions (think McD's burger onions). Turned out great! Thanks for this awesome recipe.

Holy moly I made my own pitas!! I am in shock, ha. These tasted great! I followed it just like it says. I chose to use the wet towel when they were done. I realized their shape as a circle is key. Will make again! Exciting! Thanks!

As an admitted failure at anything bread, I am thrilled that this worked. I pan fried the pitas and didn't get the puffiness (which is fine for souvlaki wraps) but the taste and texture were amazing. What wasn't used on souvlaki wraps was dipped in tzatziki sauce. Brilliant. Will make again for sure.

Easy to make and absolutely delicious! I don't have a bread machine, so as others have stated, made the dough by hand. 

To soften the bread, I tried two methods, both of which worked. First, I put a slightly damp kitchen towel in a tortilla warmer. I put the hot pita bread in the warmer, wrapping the towel around the bread, and put the lid on. The second method I used was to put a paper towel in the bottom of a gallon-sized Ziploc bag, put the hot pita bread in, and placed a paper towel on top. I then zipped up the bag. This allowed me to "steam" the bread without it getting soggy. 

By the way, I did have one bread that didn't puff up, but since the rest did so perfectly, I'm assuming that's user error on my part, not a problem with the recipe. Since I wasn't able to open it up properly, I just spread a bit of butter on it and ate it while it was still hot. Yum!

These turned out Great. Followed directions exactly till it came time to put in the oven - used baking sheets with silpats as did not have wire racks. No problems as they browned on both sides. I made these for guests and they put the whole meal over the top. No comparison with store-bought. I will make again!!
I used a tortilla press lined with a gallon sized ziploc (cut the sides off) instead of rolling out the pitas. Worked perfectly!
Great for Gyros!

It was pretty good! I changed to 1 1/2 teaspoons of salt and 2 cups flour/1 cup whole wheat flour. I had to cook the pitas for about 10 minutes before they were right. A little more sugar would've tasted better, as they were a bit bland.
I've made these repeatedly d they're always great. I like them better when they're thicker, so I make them closer to 5" across.
Very good pita bread recipe, though I made two changes. I made half the flour whole wheat and cooked on a griddle instead of the oven. It puffs up evenly and nicely and keeps in the freezer well.
Turned out great! Baked mine directly on the oven rack . They look like they'll drip over the edge, but don't worry, they puff up quickly.

I made this recipe several times before the pittas came out the way we liked them. If you use a cooling rack to cook the pitas, pre-heat the rack. Also I baked them using the convection feature and it made a huge difference. I don't use a paper bag. I place the cooked pitas between two damp dish towels. Make sure the temp of your oven is exact. A good oven thermometer is a great investment. I let mine rise an hour as 30 minutes doesn't do the trick. And - handle with care. Make sure you have enough flour on the surface when they are rising so they don't stick. The less handled the better. I can't make enough of these!

This recipe makes beautiful and perfectly puffed pita breads with perfect pockets! I don't own a bread machine and only have instant yeast on hand, so I had to deviate from the instructions. I used a stand mixer fitted with a dough hook in order to mix all of the ingredients together (note: I used 2 teaspoons of instant yeast in place of the 1 1/2 teaspoons of active dry yeast). I kneaded the dough on the mixer for approximately five minutes, until smooth. I then formed the dough into a ball and transfered into a lightly oiled bowl and covered with plastic cling wrap. I placed the bowl in a warm place to allow the dough to rest and to double in size, approximately 30 minutes. I then followed step 2; however, instead of placing the rolled pitas on the countertop, I placed them on a parchment-covered jelly roll pans -- I was able to fit 4 pitas in one half-sheet jelly roll pan. I covered the pitas with plastic cling wrap and allowed them to rest for about 30 minutes, until they were slightly puffy. When they were ready for baking, I simply removed and discarded the plastic covers and popped the jelly roll pans containing the pitas straight into the 500 °F pre-heated oven and baked until the pitas were slightly browned, about 5 minutes. After removing from the oven, I immediately placed the pitas in a large (tall) towel-lined tortilla warmer and closed the lid to allow the steam to soften them a bit. Contrary to some reviews, these pitas are soft and pliable.
haven't made yet, add a pan of water to bottom shelf when baking
I made it without using any kind of bread machine or mixer. I just activated the yeast (with warm water and sugar) first, and then set in a warm place to rise for 1.5 hours. It worked perfectly.

THIS IS AN AWESOME BREAD!! I don't have a bread machine either. I don't even like making bread, but I'll make this one again and again. After reading other reviews I chose to add a dash more salt, substitute 1 cup wheat flour for the white and used extra virgin olive oil instead of vegetable. I also brushed my pitas with olive oil prior to frying. Simply wonderful!
These turn out well for me every time. It's a little time consuming, but well worth it.

the pitas did not rise as they should, and i'll take responsibility for that. perhaps the counter was not as warm as it could have been for the last 30 minute rise before putting in the oven. as far as texture and taste, they came out fine. some could only be used as an open-faced sandwich but my wife used some as pockets. i will certainly try again to see if i have better success.

chine.

I think I might try cutting it into 6 and still make them 7". 8 rolled to 7" made them just a bit to thin and kids couldn't open the pita without ripping them. Just a little thicker and I think they'd have opened up nicer for them.

I rolled them out on parchment so I could transfer to pans quicker. Keep in mind every oven is different so watch them near the end but do it quick or heat leaves oven and affects baking.

This recipe is a staple at my house! Super simple and so delicious. My teenage boys love them. I use about 2/3 a cup of whole wheat flour in place of some of the all purpose flour, but otherwise, I make these just as the recipe describes. Thanks for a great recipe!

This came out Great - soft and delicious, and pretty easy, if you have time. Heads up - I put all eight pitas in the oven at one time, and I found the bottoms of the pitas on the lower oven rack started to burn just at the end of the baking time, because they were closest to the heat source.

INCREDIBLE! I missed pita bread so much and now I have a recipe that works and satisfies! Thank you! I'm gluten-free (health-necessity) so using this recipe with a few tweaks allowed me so much happiness that I've missed! Here are my tweaks, thanks to users and my own gf experience: I substituted gluten-free bread flour (has xanthum in it already) for the all-purpose flour. I don't have a bread maker so I proofed dry yeast in warm water with a pinch of sugar until foamy, then added all the ingredients, let it rise for ~1.5 hours, and then followed the rest of the directions. Be extra patient with rolling out: I put each ball onto a floured (same flour) square piece of wax paper to roll it then transferred the rolled out bread to a baking sheet with wax paper on it. I transferred it by picking up the small square after rolling it out and flipping it onto he big sheet with the rest (fit about 4 per a sheet). I was so impressed that a few even got the pocket even though they were gluten-free! This is a miracle recipe! Wish I could give it more stars! Thank you for this life changing recipe!

This is a fantastic recipe! I followed"sixkyej" review and advice and it was so helpful! 
I do not have a bread machine, so I proofed yeast and sugar in a separate bowl, covered with a dishtowel for 15 minutes, while I put flour, salt and vegetable oil in KitchenAid mixer. Once yeast was proofed, I added to KitchenAid and turned on speed 2 for a couple minutes. I then kneaded the dough for a few minutes on a floured surface, and transferred to a bowl which was coated in olive oil, covered with plastic wrap and a dish towel, and transferred to the oven, which I had preheated to 200 degrees while I made the dough, and turned off right before I put the bowl in. After allowing dough to rise for 45 minutes, I rolled dough into a log, divided into 8 pieces and rolled out pitas with rolling pin. I placed on baking sheet which were coated with cooking spray, and covered with plastic wrap and dish towel and allowed to rest for 30 minutes before baking in 500 degree oven for 5 minutes or so (I like my pitas a little more browned.) After removing them from oven, I immediately transferred to paper bag to soften. These didn't last long at all! I've made them twice in one week!
I thought my pita pockets were a lost cause, but most of 'em popped up in the oven and were delicious! Didn't give it a 5 star, because several of the pockets didn't rise.
Worked quite well. I tried on stove top and in oven and both worked. The stove top was a bit more difficult because I wasn't sure of the temperature.
Who knew it was that easy?! Great recipe! Thank you
Great simple pita/pocket bread recipe. Cut salt down to 1/4 tsp because of low sodium diet. Still turned out great.

I follow the recipe closely but do not cook on a wire rack. I use a cookie sheet on the next to lowest rack. I keep the oven light on so I can watch them puff out. In my oven 3 minutes in the first side and 2 minutes on the second side works great. i coner tgem with a moistened towel for 5 or 10 minutes and put them in the freezer until they are needed. Then I nuke the frozen pita for 60 seconds. If they are too moist, I will put them oin the toaster oven for a minute or so. Great foe felafel, oe cut them into wedges for humus or other dips. Peppy's pita is perfect!

I made this tonight for ground beef gyros and they were fantastic and easy! I don't have a bread machine, so I let the yeast sit in warm water for 10 minutes, then added the yeast water and oil to the dry ingredients and let that sit while I mixed the ground beef for the gyros. About 30 minutes after mixing, I separated the dough into equal portions and flattened into 6" circles. I let them sit for another half an hour while I heated a cast iron pan, and immediately before pulling the gyros from the oven I added a little olive oil to the pan and started cooking them over medium heat. I cooked them 30 seconds on the first side, flipped them and cooked for about a minute to a minute and a half. They were easy to make and a lot more delicious and soft than store bought pitas! Thank you for posting this recipe!

I have made these a handful of times and they are great my breadmachine is mussing its paddle so I make in my food processor with dough blade and it work well I usually make half regular pita and make other half into zaatar bread 3/4cup zattar blend I get at my local halal market with 1/2 cup olive oil mix well. Put pit as on a stone which I do not have so I preheat a cookie sheet upside down when I turn on oven bake put pit as on sheet add 2 or 3 tablespoons zattar leaving a edge without on pita and cook till brown on edges about 5 min at 465 Fahrenheit

The best!....I was very nervous about placing the pita on a cake cooling rack before putting in the oven......genius! I bought a rack for very little money in Wilko, thought hey ho! and cooked two in my aga. Oh boy...did these bad boys puff up?! I was so impressed. 
Thank you so much for a fab recipe.
So easy! The insides were soft and the outside crisp ! Delicious!

I am so glad to have discovered this recipe! I love the way these pitas come out. I have tried others but these are the best!!!! I am getting ready to make my second batch - the first 8 pitas have disappeared within a day! Thank you for sharing!
Delicious. I didn't have cooling racks so I cooked on stainless steel cookie sheets and they came out fine. Other than that I followed the recipe exactly.

I followed this recipe exactly, and my pitas turned out great! I'm really excited to have found this recipe. I usually buy pita breads at the store, and I find them to be very dry and crumbly. No more store bought pitas for me

I added a little bit more water 1 1/4 cup to 1 1/2 cup maybe because i used Unbleached flour. A trick to make it puff is to heat the baking sheet before putting the dough on it, you might put it in the oven while the oven is heating up. I don't have a bread machine I followed a review to mix the yeast with water and sugar first then I used my kitchenAid (don't knead so much).
These are perfect
This dough was so nice to work with! Next time around I will be sure to not roll the dough too thin... it was so neaat to watch it puff out as it cooked!

We really liked these! This pita tasted sooo much better than what we can buy in the store, and who knew it was so easy to make! I bake them on my pizza stone instead of a cake rack and turned the oven to 450 instead of 500. I've made it twice so far with good results. The second batch I forgot to roll the balls out before letting them rise. After the rising time I realized my mistake, rolled them out, and let them rise again. I was afraid they wouldn't puff up in the oven after all that, but they still puffed and came out okay! They're great with Greek salad and for sandwiches. for lunches or snacking we wrap them individually in a paper towel and microwave for 10-15 seconds. Very good!

I really liked this recipe using the breadmaking machine. It is actually a fun bread to make because it puffs up. I had no problems handling it or rolling it. I under cooked them on purpose so mine aren't as browned as the photo. Made a nice baked falafel recipe from this site to go inside. Nice for Meatless Mondays! And I have leftover bread for other types of sandwiches as a bonus.
I did not care for this recipe. Followed it to a T.... Down to the paper bag...They turned out dry.

Wow!! Definitely the keeper! Used bread maker dough setting. Instead of baking as bread, I rolled out very thin and cut it in wedges and baked (used air fryer) to make some pita chips. They were sooo yummy! The flavor and the texture was right on and I know it would make great pita bread!
This was easy and tasted amazing! We stuffed them with turkey and gruyere, and will doing that again real soon! Delish

I had to make pita bread for a school function hosting 200 people. This was the first recipe I found and it was a huge success! Next time, I'm going to try to add a little flavor to it and see what comes of it.
Great! Did everything per recipe, but "fried" in the skillet like another reviewer for a softer flat pita for my hummus craving ;)

Great! In response to the person who said a damp towel didn't work for them, try doubling them up. Worked great for me! Recipe does have denser bread than the store-bought stuff, but it's good. I'm also thinking of the chemicals i'm probably saving myself. Thanks for the recipe, Peppy/Sandy!!
Yummy bread, but I would not call it pita. I think this is more along the lines of naan or pizza crust. Will make again as such!
I just made pitas and loved it!I used half oat and half wheat flours. I used kosher salt and Might need a slight adjustment or different salt. Great anyway. Thank you.
Used a couple of ice cubes in the bottom of the oven *(put em in after hte pitas are in the oven) and cooled them in recycled grocery bakery plastic containers... worked great!
Great recipe! I don't like crispy pitas (I use them for donairs) so I "fry" my pitas in a dry frying pan. They come out soft and fluffy. Awesome to use with Dash's Donair recipe.

This must be an excellent recipe because it turned out perfect for me. I had been wanting to make pita bread and I am so glad I finally did, and chose this recipe. I have made this three times in the past week. I didn't change a thing. Of course my husband said "What have we been eating; cardboard?" I won't be buying pita bread anytime soon. Thank you for sharing your recipe Sandy.
This is a great recipe. I sub 2 cups out of 3 with whole wheat flour and I cook them on a preheated cookie sheet.

Awesome recipe with the changes noted in the comments. I too made these part whole wheat and cooked them on a very hot cast iron. Also, mixed it in my Kitchenaid. I will NEVER buy pita at the store again!

These are great. I have made them twice now, and they are easy and delicious. I don't have a bread machine, so I just mixed all the ingredients together in a mixing bowl, turned the dough onto a board and kneaded it until it was a soft dough. Then I put it in a greased bowl to rise about an hour and a half. After that I followed the directions, except I don't have a wire cake rack so I baked them on a cookie sheet dusted generously with flour. That worked fine and they didn't stick to the cookie sheet. I just dusted off the extra flour when they were done. We ate them with homemade hummus, veggies and goat cheese. Yum!
